Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
> Hi Joe,
> 
> Joe Schmetzer wrote:
>  >
>  > >I've just updated the JUnit Anti-patterns page I maintain at
>  > >http://www.exubero.com/junit/antipatterns.html. I'd be interested in
>  > >any feedback, if people want to suggest additions or improvements.
> I don't really understand this:
> 
> This is a design decision that permeates JUnit, and when you decide to
> report multiple failures per test, you begin to fight against JUnit.

I would think this refers to wanting later assertions to execute after a 
previous assertion fails, which JUnit doesn't do on purpose.

> I don't see how having more that one assert "fights against" JUnit (what
> does this even mean?) and in the code that I see every day, very few tests
> contain only one assert.  Especially if your tests require two or three
> statements to set up in the test method (not in setUp()), in which case
> there is even more to be gained to run more than one assert so you don't
> have to duplicate this code in other test methods.

I see many people misunderstand the message of "one assert per test". 
It's not important to have precisely one assert per test, but it is 
generally wise to avoid doing this:

arrange
act
assert
act some more
assert some more
act some more
assert some more

Let me emphasize that this is /generally/ unwise. Not always so. (I 
usually split this into three separate tests.)

> Also, the fix you show in your documentation is simplistic.  What if the
> code to be extracted is specific to that test method?  If you move it to
> setUp(), you are suddenly charging *all* the other test methods of that same
> class with this set up cost that they have no need for.
> 
> Also, it seems to me your recommended pattern for code that must throw an
> exception ("don't catch it and declare the exception in the throws
> statement") goes against common practice.  Plus, it will cause JUnit to
> report an Error instead of a Failure, although this distinction is
> thankfully going away with JUnit4.
> 
> A more common way to address this problem is to catch the exception and do a
> fail().

I don't quite understand this. If the test expects the exception, then 
we usually catch it and /don't/ fail; but if the test doesn't expect the 
exception, then we usually throw it up into JUnit and let it report the 
error.
